channel.title: Home on defPhil
channel.description: Recent content in Home on defPhil

item.title: Objects vs Lambdas
item.description: Change of perception after going functional route This won't be another "Oh my god, SICP changed my life and the way I look at software" blog post. Although it did certainly have significant impact on my perception on how to write software, I want to talk about something a little bit different today. And that is how I started thinking about Object Oriented Programming from different point of view than before I got my feet wet with functional paradigm.

item.title: Abstraction contraction
item.description: Software and it's weird nature The most exciting and weird thing I found out about in early teenage days was software. I started my journey with TurboPASCAL on start of my second year of high school. It felt really weird at first, mostly because I kinda expected from computers to be magicaly less stupid than they actualy were. "What? I have to tell them when I am about to use natural number, wtf?

item.title: Gonzo Science
item.description: Seeing the white rabbit Yesterday I've finished reading What the Dormouse Said and The Soul of a New Machine. First I have to make a confession. I always had weak spot for 60s in America. It is such distant place for me, both geographically and by time, but it always impressed me and inspired me, don't know why. I was hooked up on Rock 'n' Roll when I was a kid, it was influence from my uncle.

item.title: about me
item.description: # Code & Math I first started programming in early days of high school. My father is electrical engineer, so I was exposed to computers and electronics since age of three. He brought me some books about programming in Pascal. Previous to that I was mostly playing with Linux, configuring it, writing some scripts and modding games. I didnâ€™t have a feeling of actually writing software until that point. Near the end of high school I attended Computer Science courses in International Science Center Petnica.
